ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: OMG I loved this course so much as it was so different from all other Public Health courses. We had hands-on experience of doing actual bench work that corresponded to the lecture, which was so good and impressive.
Really enjoyed the lecture material and especially the laboratory components. The assignments were somewhat confusing -- didn't really know when they were due or what to expect.

Good material, although not always up-to-date Allows for hands-on experience with laboratory techniques; accessible for those that are non-savvy or uninitiated. More labs would enhance experience Decent course for outlining and emphasizing the importance of the biological components of disease and the research methods required to investigate the contribution of genetics/epigenetics to health outcomes.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Yong Zhu  He was such a knowledgeable faculty that I learned a lot from his lectures.
Instructor: Yong Zhu   Knowledgeable. Approachable. Helpful. Always inviting questions/conversations Engagement dependent on student participation, so lulls can occur

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: If you want to have a different aspect of public health from molecular standpoint, take this course, as it is not has difficult as those taught in the biomedical science department and you can also have hands-on experience on lab work.
Good if you have some background in molecular biology. Probably best suited for someone with molecular interests in chronic diseases

Decent, mid-level intro course for outlining and emphasizing the importance of the biological components of disease and the research methods required to investigate the contribution of genetics/epigenetics to health outcomes.
